Project Number: 44501-001 
Policy and Advisory Technical Assistance (PATA) 
December 2010 
 
 
 
People’s Republic of China: Study on Eco-
Compensation Regulations

Vice-President  C. Lawrence Greenwood, Jr., Operations 2

In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During the country programming midterm review mission held in Beijing in June 2010, 
the government asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance (TA) 
to help the People’s Republic of China (PRC) ensure that international best practice approaches 
are incorporated in the development of national eco-compensation legislation. ADB received a 
written proposal prepared by the Department of Western Region Development of the National 
Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) in August 2010. The proposal indicates that the 
development of an ecological compensation ordinance is listed as a legislative program to be 
drafted by NDRC. At the request of the PRC  government, ADB fielded a reconnaissance 
mission to Beijing in September 2010, and held discussions with NDRC to clarify and agree on 
the scope, impact, outcome, outputs, costs, and financing arrangements for the TA. Following a 
successful conference on the payment for ecosystem services (PES) in 2009, ADB and NDRC 
jointly organized a second international conference on PES in October 2010 with a focus on 
eco-compensation legislation and payments for watershed services. The TA for a study on eco-
compensation regulations was presented and discussed during that conference. The TA builds 
on past and ongoing ADB achievements and interventions, and focuses specifically on bringing 
in global best practice approaches in the development of national eco-compensation legislation 
in the PRC. The PES mechanism supports ADB’s strategic priorities in Strategy 2020,1 which 
aims  to  promote  inclusive  economic  growth,  environmental  sustainability,  and  regional 
integration.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  Natural systems like forests, wetlands, and watersheds provide a wide variety of goods 
and  services,  and  contribute  to  human  well-being  and  poverty  reduction.3 Many  of  these 
services are provided indirectly, i.e., with no direct link between the service provider and the 
consumer of the service, perhaps due to the spatial separation between the environmental 
services providers (often landowners or resource managers in the upper watershed) and the 
users of the same environmental services (beneficiaries such as consumers of potable water, or 
industries or agriculture located downstream). Therefore, the market for these services is often 
not  present  and  the  ecosystem  managers  have  little  economic  incentive  to  improve 
environmental  management.  As  a  result,  in  most  places,  environmental  services  are 
undersupplied, therefore fewer or inferior quality services are made available than desirable. 
 
3.  In the PRC, the traditional approach to ensure the provision of environmental services 
has been through eco-compensation payments made directly from the government to providers 
of environmental services. PES-related regulations have also been mainly limited to local areas. 
However,  since  2005, the  State  Council  has  been  giving  urgency  to the  establishment  of 
effective  ecological  compensation  mechanisms.  The  government  continues  to  assign  high 
priority to the protection of the ecological environment.  
 
4.  The  government  recently  emphasized  the  need  to  revisit  the  legal  and  institutional 
mechanisms for environment protection. In 2008, the Decision of the Central Committee of the 
Communist  Party  of  China  on  Several  Significant  Issues  in  Promoting  Rural  Reform  and 
Development adopted in the Third Plenary Session of the 17th Communist Party of China 
Central Committee stressed the need for an incentive mechanism to facilitate the protection of 
                                                
1  ADB. 2008. Strategy 2020: The Long-Term Strategic Framework of the Asian Development Bank, 2008–2020. 
Manila. 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 1 Dec 2010. 
3  Millennium Ecosystem Assessment. http://www.maweb.org/

2   
such  natural  resources  as  arable  lands,  water  areas,  forests,  grasslands,  wetlands,  and 
agricultural species resources.  
 
5.  The improved regulatory framework resulting from this TA will contribute to enhancing 
environmental sustainability. The national eco-compensation legislative framework aims to set 
principles that will help clarify rights and responsibilities over ecosystem services and natural 
resources, resolving equity issues, and improving strategic environmental planning. This effort 
will stimulate innovation in environmental policy, including the development of more incentive-
based  management  regimes,  and  greater  adoption  of  and  innovation  in  market-based 
instruments.    
 
6.  ADB supported the first and second international conferences on PES in the PRC in 
November 2009 and October 2010. The TA will build on past and ongoing ADB interventions 
and focus specifically on introducing global best practice approaches in the development of 
national eco-compensation legislation in the PRC. The lessons and issues identified at these 
conferences have provided the basis for the formulation of the TA.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The  TA  will  contribute  to  improved  environmental  management  and  sustainable 
development in the PRC by adding value to the overall eco-compensation policy development 
process. The impact of the TA is improved legislation for environmental management and 
sustainable development in the PRC. The TA will support the government in achieving its 
broader  objectives  of  attaining  an  “ecological  civilization,”4 and  support  the  government  in 
meeting  its  targets  of  having  the  highest  legislation  in  place  for  issues  related  to  eco-
compensation.  The  outcome  is  that  national  eco-compensation  legislation  in  the  PRC  is 
developed.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  Output 1: National drafting team trained and a review on international approaches 
in eco-compensation and PES legislation prepared. The TA will enable capacity building of 
the national eco-compensation legislation drafting team on international approaches with regard 
to PES legislation. The specific activities include (i) two teams (of five individuals each) conduct 
study tours to two separate groups of countries (proposed destinations group 1: Australia and 
New Zealand; and group 2: Norway, Switzerland, and the United Kingdom); and (ii) prepare 
review reports on legislation relating to PES and eco-compensation in the visited countries, 
document the learning experience, and make a presentation at the midterm workshop.  
 
9.  Output 2: Detailed technical (thematic) study reports on nine focal areas of eco-
compensation. The nine thematic study reports will focus on the following eco-compensation 
focal  areas:  (i)  legislative  framework  for  eco-compensation,  (ii)  wetland  eco-compensation, 
(iii) forest ecological benefit compensation, (iv) regional eco-compensation approaches, (v) river 
basin  eco-compensation,  (vi)  compensation  for  exploitation  and  utilization  of  resources,  
                                                
4  The concept of “ecological civilization” in the PRC is a future-oriented guiding principle based on the perception of 
the extremely high price the country has paid for the economic miracle. The concept reflects an important change 
in the PRC's understanding of development. Rather than emphasizing economic construction as the core of 
development as in the past, the government has come to realize that development, if sustainable, must entail a list 
of elements including the right relationship between man and nature. (China Daily. 2007. Ecological Civilization. 
http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/opinion/2007-10/24/content_6201964.htm)

3 
(vii) marine eco-compensation, (viii) collection of ecological compensation tax, and (ix) modeling 
of eco-compensation impacts on the economy. The thematic field studies will be conducted in 
selected  provinces  across  the  country.  They  will  capture  the  various  local  innovative 
approaches  being  used  in  the  PRC  to  provide  guidance  for  the  development  of  national 
legislation.  Local  thematic  workshops  will  be  organized  with  participants  from  the  various 
government  sectors  and  civil  society  representation.  The  wide-ranging  participation  at  the 
workshops  will  ensure  discussion  on  ecosystem  and  livelihood  issues  in  relation  to  eco-
compensation legislation development. The thematic studies will be led by the relevant thematic 
experts  under  the  guidance  of  the  lead  expert,  with  input  from  the  international  expert. 
Workshop reports will be made available.   
 
10.  Output 3: First draft of national eco-compensation legislation for the PRC. Based 
on international experience (i.e., output 1), input from the thematic study reports and local 
thematic workshops (output 2), the national drafting team will prepare the first draft of the eco-
compensation regulations. The drafting team will undertake the drafting process in accordance 
with national procedures.   
 
11.  Output 4: An appropriate knowledge product on lessons from the development of 
eco-compensation legislation based on the PRC experience. The specific objective and 
scope of the knowledge product has not yet been determined. This will be decided through a 
consultative process during TA implementation. However the overall purpose of the knowledge 
product will be to highlight the importance of a regulatory framework for eco-compensation in 
the PRC context, to document how international best-practice principles have been incorporated 
into the draft PRC eco-compensation regulation development process, and to document and 
communicate some of the innovative policy approaches currently being taken in the PRC with 
regard to PES.  
  
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA cost is estimated at $600,000 equivalent, of which $500,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  (TASF–other  sources).  The 
government will finance the remaining $100,000 equivalent in local currency through in-kind 
contribution, which will include (i) counterpart staff time, remuneration, and travel expenses;  
(ii) logistic support in arranging workshops and conferences; and (iii) costs such as for acquiring 
foreign legislation information, translation of documents, and steering committee meetings. The 
cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The Department of Western Region Development of NDRC is the executing agency for 
the TA. A project management office will be set up within NDRC and be responsible for day-to-
day TA operations, including overseeing the TA consultants’ work plans, reviewing their outputs, 
and  coordinating  with  the  consultants  for  the  preparation  of  the  national  and  provincial 
workshops.  An  advance  payment  facility  will  be  established  for  TA  implementation.  TA 
implementation will be closely coordinated with various agencies, particularly with the Ministry of 
Environmental Protection.5  
 
                                                
5  The Ministry of Environmental Protection is currently the executing agency for another ADB TA project related to 
eco-compensation, i.e., ADB. 2008. Technical Assistance to the People’s Republic of China for Preparing National 
Guidelines for Eco-Compensation in River Basins and a Framework for Soil Pollution Management (TA 7217-
PRC).

4   
14.  The  State  Council  has  approved  the  development  of  national  eco-compensation 
legislation and mandated NDRC to take the lead on this. NDRC has therefore established a 
high-level  multisector  leading  group  (chaired  by  the  vice  minister  of  NDRC),  and  another 
multisector working group (the drafting team) with representation from all relevant line ministries. 
These will ensure close coordination and input from all agencies throughout TA implementation. 
To oversee TA implementation, the leading group will function as the steering committee.   
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 24 months, tentatively scheduled from March 2011 to 
February 2013. Ten individual consultants will be engaged to conduct studies that contribute to 
the drafting of the eco-compensation legislation. An estimated 62.5 person-months of consulting 
services will comprise the services of an international expert for 3.5 person-months and nine 
individual national experts for 59 person-months. ADB will engage the consultants following its 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The individual 
consultant  selection  modality  will  be  used  because  studies  related  to  eco-compensation 
legislation comprise a highly specialized subject; thus identifying an available firm with sufficient 
expertise to implement this study would be difficult. In addition, separate responsibilities are 
required to produce the nine thematic reports. The outline terms of reference for the consultants 
are in Appendix 3. A proposed outline for the thematic study report is provided in Appendix 4. 
The  TA  proceeds  will  be  disbursed  following  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). Both the team leader and deputy team leader 
will each be responsible for one thematic area. The specific terms of reference for the seven 
experts will be elaborated by the team leader, international consultant, and deputy team leader, 
upon refinement of the study framework. 
 
16.  The outcome and outputs of the TA will be presented during national workshops and 
posted on the ADB and NDRC websites. The TA will produce a knowledge product (i.e. output 4) 
based on lessons from TA implementation. The scope and target audience for the knowledge 
product will be determined during TA implementation. This will in turn determine the specific 
communication strategies and plans for the dissemination of the knowledge product.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to 
the People’s Republic of China for the Study on Eco-Compensation Regulations, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.

4.  Deputy team leader and wetland PES specialist (national, 8 person-months). The 
specialist will provide support to the team leader in overall coordination and supervision of the 
TA activities and outputs, and liaison with ADB and NDRC and other national government 
agencies supporting the related work. The deputy team leader will  
(i)  support the team leader to develop the detailed study framework, coordinate the 
individual  studies,  review  and  coordinate  individual  studies,  and  organize 
workshops; 
(ii)  function  as  leading  expert  on  the  thematic  study  area  of  wetland  eco-
compensation and PES (para. 6); 
(iii)  assist in developing and refining the specific terms of reference for the leading 
experts of the remaining thematic study areas; 
(iv)  support the team leader in managing and ensuring timely implementation of the 
project activities; 
(v)  support the team leader in preparing the national eco-compensation drafting 
team for the respective international legislation review missions; 
(vi)  lead in the drafting of the thematic study report on wetland eco-compensation; 
and support the team leader in reviewing the other reports, eco-compensation 
legislation, and other related reports; 
(vii)  support  the  team  leader  in  the  preparation  and  review  of  the  TA  inception, 
midterm, and final reports; and revision of chapters and sections; and 
(viii)  organize and give presentations in workshops and seminars. 
 
5.  Thematic experts (7 national experts, 6 person-months each) on the following proposed 
thematic focal areas: (i) forest ecological benefit compensation, (ii) regional eco-compensation 
approaches, (iii) river basin eco-compensation, (iv) compensation for exploitation and utilization 
of resources, (v) marine eco-compensation, (vi) collection of ecological compensating tax, and 
(vii) modeling of eco-compensation impacts on the economy. 
 
6.  General terms of reference for the thematic experts include 
(i)  identify lessons from the PRC and internationally in the respective thematic focal 
areas; 
(ii)  implement at least two field case studies in the PRC in each of the thematic focal 
areas; the case study involves the regulatory framework, stakeholder (ecosystem 
services providers and beneficiaries, and others) analysis, compensation rate, 
payment vehicles, compensation mechanisms, and cost-benefit analysis; 
(iii)  convene a workshop in each of the field sites to review and assess the case 
study results with participants comprising local government officials and peer 
specialists; 
(iv)  provide a report on the thematic study, which records the lessons in the thematic 
focal area, case study results, and response to the comments and revisions by 
the workshop participants;

Appendix 3  11 
(v)  participate in the TA inception, midterm, and final workshops; and provide inputs 
needed for inception, midterm, and final reports; and 
(vi)  participate  in  international  seminars  on  eco-compensation  sponsored  by  the 
executing agency, and present study results in the thematic areas. 
 
7.  Details of the terms of reference will be developed by the team leader, with support from 
the deputy team leader and international specialist, in consultation with ADB. The experts will be 
engaged for the preparation of the thematic studies (para. 5).
